content.html:
Technical Notes:

1. Accelerometer-based hydro-acoustic sensors are also known as vector sensors.

2. 'Acceleration sensitivity' is defined as twenty times the logarithm to the base 10 of the ratio of rms output voltage to a 1 V rms reference, when the hydro-acoustic sensor, without a preamplifier, is placed in a plane wave acoustic field with an rms acceleration of 1 g (i.e., 9.81 m/s 2).
content.text: Technical Notes: 1. Accelerometer-based hydro-acoustic sensors are also known as vector sensors. 2. content.text: Note: 6A001.a.2 also applies to receiving equipment, whether or not related in normal application to separate active equipment, and “specially designed” “components” therefor.

content.html:
Technical Notes:

1. Accelerometer-based hydro-acoustic sensors are also known as vector sensors.

2. 'Acceleration sensitivity' is defined as twenty times the logarithm to the base 10 of the ratio of rms output voltage to a 1 V rms reference, when the hydro-acoustic sensor, without a preamplifier, is placed in a plane wave acoustic field with an rms acceleration of 1 g (i.e., 9.81 m/s 2).

6A001 Acoustic systems, equipment and “components,” as follows (see List of Items Controlled).
Lead-indium-niobate/lead-magnesium niobate/lead-titanate (i.e., Pb(In1/2Nb1/2)O3-Pb(Mg1/3Nb2/3)O3-PbTiO3, or PIN-PMN-PT) piezoelectric single crystals grown from solid solution;
Passive systems, equipment and “specially designed” “components” therefor, as follows:

structure.heading: Accelerometer-based hydro-acoustic sensors having all of the following:

content.text: a.2.g.1. Composed of three accelerometers arranged along three distinct axes;

children.heading: Having an overall 'acceleration sensitivity' better than 48 dB (reference 1,000 mV rms per 1g);
children.label: 6A001.a.2.g.2 – Having an overall 'acceleration sensitivity' better than 48 dB (reference 1,000 mV rms per 1g);

content.html: a.2.g.2. Having an overall 'acceleration sensitivity' better than 48 dB (reference 1,000 mV rms per 1g);
content.text: a.2.g.2. Having an overall 'acceleration sensitivity' better than 48 dB (reference 1,000 mV rms per 1g);

children.heading: Designed to operate at depths greater than 35 meters; and
children.label: 6A001.a.2.g.3 – Designed to operate at depths greater than 35 meters; and

children.heading: Operating frequency below 20 kHz;
children.label: 6A001.a.2.g.4 – Operating frequency below 20 kHz;

content.html: a.2.g.4. Operating frequency below 20 kHz;
content.text: a.2.g.4. Operating frequency below 20 kHz;

content.html:
Note:

6A001.a.2.g does not apply to particle velocity sensors or geophones.
content.text: Note: 6A001.a.2.g does not apply to particle velocity sensors or geophones.

content.html:
Technical Notes:

1. Accelerometer-based hydro-acoustic sensors are also known as vector sensors.

2. 'Acceleration sensitivity' is defined as twenty times the logarithm to the base 10 of the ratio of rms output voltage to a 1 V rms reference, when the hydro-acoustic sensor, without a preamplifier, is placed in a plane wave acoustic field with an rms acceleration of 1 g (i.e., 9.81 m/s 2).

content.html:
Technical Notes:

1. Accelerometer-based hydro-acoustic sensors are also known as vector sensors.

2. 'Acceleration sensitivity' is defined as twenty times the logarithm to the base 10 of the ratio of rms output voltage to a 1 V rms reference, when the hydro-acoustic sensor, without a preamplifier, is placed in a plane wave acoustic field with an rms acceleration of 1 g (i.e., 9.81 m/s 2).

1. For the purposes of 6A001.a.2.g, accelerometer-based hydro-acoustic sensors are also known as vector sensors.

2. For the purposes of 6A001.a.2.g.2, 'acceleration sensitivity' is defined as twenty times the logarithm to the base 10 of the ratio of rms output voltage to a 1 V rms reference, when the hydro-acoustic sensor, without a preamplifier, is placed in a plane wave acoustic field with an rms acceleration of 1 g (i.e., 9.81 m/s2).
